description: Niji is one of my go-to lunch spots. The owner and entire staff are really kind and helpful. They know me at this point and as soon as I walk in they remember my order and it's ready in just a few minutes. Great service!! Solid lunch every time.
author: DeAnna C.

description:
Niji has always been a solid option for food. I usually get their udon and tempura combo if it's cold outside. They also have fantastic bento box options with soup if you're in the mood for it. There aren't a ton of sushi places in the area and many closed down due to the increasingly high cost of doing business in the city. 

I picked up my combination maki and miso soup for lunch here. It was a solid meal and again no line at 11:45am (I really should start going to lunch before noon). They already had my order ready to go and I was out the door in no time. It was definitely a good deal the combination consists of 3 piece California roll, 3 piece unagi roll, 3 piece kappa roll, 3 piece ebi roll, and 1 piece inari roll.
author: Tim G.

description: Mediocre food. Had the tempura soba deal. The soba was gluey and the dipping sauce bland. The tempura was not tempura batter and the and the dipping sauce was bland. Service was without a smile. Never coming here again...
author: Mi M.

description:
Got a MealPal here (9 pc rolls) which was fine.

Service could be improved. One cashier was great, the other who handed me food made absolutely no eye contact and responded to my "thank you" with a grunt while staring into space.
author: Barack O.

description:
$10.86 for brown rice w/white meat chicken combo - not bad..but

- salad looked pretty sad/brown
- teriyaki sauce very sweet
- brown rice tasted like microwave/instant

not bad bang for buck, just not the highest quality ingredients. could do better at dragon eats or bibimbar for this price
author: Kristie C.

description: This place should go out of Business. I tried the flavorless rubbery unseasoned chicken donburi and was very disappointed. To make matters worse I had an upset stomach after eating this meal. I will not go back here.
author: Kam H.

description: portions are small, and food is mediocre for the price. Do yourself a favor and find another place.
author: Alister S.

description:
One of my offices is downtown, so I travelled down the food court of this open mall to try this place.

Man, was that a bad decision.

I should have stuck with my work's vending machine.

As in a cup of ramen would have been better and cheaper than their salmon bento.

Care for overcooked salmon with a bland teriyaki sauce?

Or how about burned gyoza?

Yeah, me neither.

And at $15.00 I was like, what happened here?

Take a look at my plate and tell me this doesn't look like some kid chef made this.

Complete with a cheap plate too.

Oh, and beware of the salty miso soup. You'll need tons of water to wash this salt bath down.
author: Jack R.

description: So good! I've been to Niji a few times since they are close to work. I have never been disappointed. They are very generous with their servings. I get a combo plate whenever I'm feeling gluttonous and a plate of steamed broccoli over rice when I need something quick and cheap!
author: Shiela D.

description:
Just wanted to say that this place is AWESOME!!! Excellent Food and the people that work here treat their Customers just right and with outstanding Service! If you're at the Galleria in SF and are looking for a great place to eat Japanese food with a price that is extremely reasonable for the amount of food you get this is it!!! Thank you Niji for the Superior Service and food!!!

Jim H.
author: jim h.

description: I have been coming here for the last 15 years and it is consistently good... the quality has not changed, the people are friendly, and their salmon teriyaki is my choice...
author: Gears J.

description:
It's a little restaurant for lunch in Crocker Galleria, Financial District.  Too bad the location isn't that great.  It's tucked all the way at the end of the top floor and competing with other restaurants during peak hours.  The good thing is that they offer basic Japanese food if you want to fix that craving you have of yours - because that is exactly what I did.

I went here to get my udon fix and they offer sushi.  I was really craving for udon during lunch and yelped where in my vicinity would have it.  This restaurant popped up on top when I searched for udon!  

So I went here and ordered udon, of course.  Simple presentation.  Thinner than usual on the udon texture, a bit on the salty side for their soup and too sweet with their yellow melons that they provide in their udon bowl.  My suggestion is to cancel that sweetness of those sliced up yellow melons by sprinkling Japanese chili powder on top of everything and sipping on some of that hot soup.  

Good service, but the cafe lacks ambiance and Japanese decor.  Their food quality lacks a Japanese cute (kawaii) style to it as well.

I wouldn't be back unless I am really craving for udon again!
author: Tiffany D.

description: The salmon was tender and the soy sauce that comes with it has a nice kick of ginger. The salad dressing could have been better. The rice was a bit too mushy for my taste.
author: James S.

description: omg I love the gyu don here. I can eat them three days in a row.
author: Pai-Wei L.

description:
So far so good!

I've been here twice. 
The first time I got ramen and the second time I got tonkatsu. Both times the food was delicious. For the tonkatsu, I went right before they closed on a Friday and had no problems with wilted salad or a weird watery substance in the pork. And as far as table service, you guys have got to be joking right? You're going to an outdoor mall food court and expect top notch table service? Gtfoutta here!
author: Amanda M.

description: Food looks good, but tastes just okay.The chicken in teriyaki is so hard and chewy to eat.
author: Louis X.

description:
This place is really good for the price. It is also fairly quick and convenient if you are in the Financial District. I like the chicken teriyaki meal best. It is all breast meat and they offer brown rice as a $1 upgrade. Miso soup comes with it and is really good. The salad is a little boring (iceberg lettuce), but I really like the dressing.

This is definitely one of my regular spots when I have to do a quick lunch.
author: Dean B.

description: Bland blah Japanese fast food - nothing to write home about. Miso soup was nicely salted. Salmon wasn't great.
author: Andrew K.

description: Far from an actual Sushi joint, if that's what you're looking for.  The place is ok, if you're looking for a quick chicken or salmon teriyaki fix.  Other than that the rolls aren't extensive and don't carry sashimi
author: Mike S.

description:
I've been coming here frequently and every time I'm never disappointed. Obviously, it's not gonna be like your fancy, extremely authentic dine-in for dinner Japanese restaurants. But it's definitely reasonably priced for how much you get and how fast you get it. 

I love getting sushi here because it's always fresh and definitely affordable. I like the spicy tuna or tempura shrimp maki because they give a lot in each roll. When I'm not feeling sushi, I get their katsu and tempura. In general, I'm not a big fan of teriyaki, but their homemade sauce is pretty good. 

A combo meal comes with salad, rice, broccoli, and soup. I'd recommend their shioyaki (citrus, salt grilled) dishes, which are very light and delicious. And adding 3 pieces of california rolls or a whole side of tempura for only $1.00 to your combo?? I can't complain. I've chatted with the owners a few times and they seem very friendly. For a fast food Japanese restaurant located in a mall food court, this place is definitely a great go-to for lunch!
author: Rachel H.

description: A staple for my lunch time break in FiDi. Why? Because it's cheap, quick, and tasty! I go for the chicken donburi, extra broccoli, sauce on the side. Under $8 and I'm a happy camper.
author: Angela D.

description: Restaurant was clean and spacious. Friendly server. I had the edamame which tasted good but looked not so great. I had the Bento box with chicken teriyaki, spicy salmon roll and spicy tuna roll. All of that was good.
author: Jim R.

description: Wow, chicken teriyaki was so dry that I thought I was eating cardboard covered in generic Teriyaki sauce.  Broccoli was just plainly steamed with no seasoning, which I guess is ok for the health-minded peeps, and your salad is brown-ish iceberg lettuce.  Had tons better for $10.  On the upside, they're located at Crocker and servers are nice enough and work efficiently.  But if you want Bento, the Japanese spot in the Underground food court is about 10 times better, and they're only just above average.
author: J S.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Friday with a couple fellow interns. Niji is a little place in Crocker Galleria, where many other restaurants tout their fast casual cuisine. Not a fancy or trendy restaurant, as it seems to be built to optimize the lunch-time rush. Everything was served on paper plates, and even the soup came in plastic bowls. Not very eco-friendly.

I ordered the tempura combination, which comes with soup, salad, and rice. All the food came out within 5 minutes. I always love Japanese-style salad dressing, so I enjoyed the salad. Miso soup was good, though it'd be pretty hard to mess up miso soup. The portion size was large: there were three pieces of shrimp tempura and then tons of vegetables (zucchini, broccoli, etc). The food was decent.

I feel a little bad giving 3-stars as that's based off comparing Niji with most normal Japanese places. It's certainly not up there in terms of quality. But if you aren't picky for lunch, I'd say to consider Niji to be rated a little higher as it serves its purpose--fast Japanese food.
author: Tina T.

description:
I wanted to try something different in Crocker Galleria and it was a bad decision. The line was busy so I thought it would be really good, but right from the start I should've known to go somewhere else. 

The actual restaurant is kind of dingy. There's duct tape on the counter (saw this after I ordered) and the drink machine is an eyesore.

I ordered the Tonkatsu (pork cutlet). It came out pretty quick, but once I got it, the salad was wilted, the pork cutlet was sitting in a brothy substance and the rice was nothing to rave about. The flavors were there but nothing else was. Table service was also lacking. Wish this place was better!
author: Brandon K.

description:
Place wasnt terrible. Coworker hella loves the teriyaki, so i tried it, and also got the shrimp tempura add on. Decent volume of food. Tempura was good because it was fried. The chicken teriyaki seriously had zero taste or character though. It was just a not well grillt piece of chicken with sauce doused on it. Did they even marinate?_? At least it came with salad and soop.

I may try something else if i get tired of the chinese food or other offerings around the area, but until then, sad sawce.

My name is Boris Yelpsin, and I approve this message.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Nobody would ever seek this place out nor should they.  But if you find yourself lunching with co-workers at the Crocker Galleria and they all head to Chaat Cafe and you can't stomach one more Indian meal this week, it's nice to know this place is here.  

The Crocker Galleria's top floor is basically a big food court, so everyone can get what they want (as long as it's Mexican, Indian, Japanese, or Soup).   

My tempura was good.  My soba noodles (hey, that was just buckwheat spaghetti!) fine, if inauthentic.  there was nothing more on my plate, hence nothing more to review.
author: Tracey A.

description: Decent Japanese food to fulfill a craving during lunch. I like the chicken katsu combo with salad and miso soup. Costs about $9.50 with tax so pricey but average for the area. You do get a good amount of edamame for $3.50 if you get that, eat some now and then have a healthy snack for later
author: Erin T.

description: Great little restaurant. It is good food, cheap and fast and they have their own indoor seating unlike many of the other restaurants in this mall. I had the beef bowl and the beef was very tender and flavorful. I will be back.
author: Sunil R.

description: I always order the spicy tuna roll, miso soup and or California roll.  The spicy tuna roll is my favorite!  The prices are in line w the rest of the lunch in the Financial District and it's pretty good for a to go Japanese lunch!
author: Darlene T.

description: It was very quick serving, right after I paid, but the chicken teriyaki I didn't like. Seemed like the chicken was a little hard and not fully cooked. Salad seemed to be a little old. Place seems to be nice, location is awesome, but I expected the food to be better.
author: Yuliya M.

description:
It has been a while since I was here last.  I had the chicken teriyaki with soup, rice and salad (to go).

The chicken appeared to have been boiled and then put on grill for a minute before being doused with sweet teriyaki sauce (lacked sesoning and bbq char...dry and bland)  broccoli was in the same section of the container, placed under the chicken; it was totally saturated with the sweet sauce but was okay after I threw it a life preserver and drained it. Typical little side salad that you get with Asian take out;  bag salad with a miso mayo based dressing- salad was green and as fresh as bag salad can be. Rice was good as well as the soup. Not as good as I had remembered, but willing to give it another chance.   PS  couldn't finish the chicken
author: Philip W.

description: An excellent Good Friday option. Salmon Teriyaki Donburi lunch was good for the price. Your downtown so lunch = $10 minimum. The food was served fast and the place is clean. The piece of salmon was a good sized piece. Lin used to getting a tiny sliver of fish whenever I order a salmon dish for lunch. The broccoli portion was also better than most. I think I heard brown rice was an option also. I'lol be back for sure.
author: Rob M.

description: I ordered the Chicken teriyaki... the vegetables were cold... the soup was like water.  I had tuna sushi which I barfed up caused it tasted so bad.   The photos looked good, too bad the food didn't match.   I've had better food at a fast food restaurant and much cheaper.
author: Alice K.

description:
Wow, what a rip off.

I come here from time to time for the simple udon, but decided to try one of their menu items for a change - bad idea. I ordered the Yakitori Donburi  and all I got was chicken teriyaki. Where was my damn egg & veggies? Why did I even bother paying the extra money? Ugh. So frustrated.

I've never been back since. I suggest you take your business elsewhere.
author: Jenny T.

description:
This is a great place if you work close to the crocker galleria 
If I need a quick sushi fix I call it in and it's ready by the time I get there fresh tasty sushi !
author: lyn m.

description:
Continues to be a stable lunch spot for me. No matter how late it gets (close to 3pm sometimes), I can always count on a hot bowl of soba or freshly made sushi. 

Yes, the sushi is overpriced and the selection is minimal, but the ingredients are alwasy fresh and service is fast. 

Portions and prices are pretty good on other items and I'm excited to see a Miso Ramen on their menu today.....will definitely give that a try.
author: Maggie C.

description: Healthy portions of chicken .... Sad, not really green salad with the special. Not really memorable, I had the chicken teriyaki, which was a little too sweet, almost tasted poached. Good for a quick meal, if you're not a foodie.
author: Evan H.

description: Decent food but the guy taking the orders is the worst thing about this place. Every time I've been there he's been rude and unhelpful. He doesn't speak up and is kind of a dick. He's always there and the only one taking orders, so this can't be confused with anyone else. That guy sucks and makes this restaurant experience much worse than it should be.
author: Drew P.

description:
Not fine Japanese dining by any means, but pretty good. I had the saba (mackerel) shioyaki and the cashier said it'd take ten minutes to cook. I guess I was starving so it felt a lot longer, but when it came out the fish was crispy and hot and really yummy. Portions are filling and the price is reasonable.

Edit: Actually, this place beats the crap out of 99% of the places in Japantown, which is kinda shameful for the JTown people.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Niji is great! Especially on those days where I want something soft on the stomach but strong on the tongue! I usually order the Chicken teriyaki combo and add tempura for like $1.50, for a total meal under $10. It's more than enough food, especially with the miso soup and the salad. Their dressing is delicious btw.
author: Andrew C.

description:
My colleague & I had a $3 off coupon for lunch anywhere in Crocker Galleria and decided to try Niji. We each ordered some to-go sushi (spicy tuna and oshinko maki) and waited by the counter. And waited. And waited some more, while all around us hot plates were going out. I guess that is a good sign that they don't have the rolls pre-made?
Anyway, we finally got our food and took it back to our office around the corner. The sushi was actually really good - the tuna seemed fresh and wasn't drowned in spicy mayo. And there was a healthy amount of tuna in the roll! The oshinko was delicious - perfectly pickled. They included three packets of soy sauce and a huge mound of fresh-pickled ginger as well. All in all, a pretty solid lunch for only $5.19!

I will probably be back to try one of the combinations with salmon or saba shioyaki - I saw one walk by and it looked good. I can see the udon as good comfort food on a rainy day as well.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
So when is average good? When you're talking about downtown lunch options. No, the average downtown lunch option isn't good. It's frightfully bad. Which is why an average lunch joint anywhere my office gets semi-regular business from me.

The salmon teriyaki is my favorite.  Though the included soup and salad are nothing special, and the broccoli is always lukewarm.  The mackerel is decent too.  Hey, it's fast and the price is right...

Please, someone tell me where to get great sushi at a reasonable price downtown!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Ted R.

description:
MAN, why did we come here?  Oh yeah, cause Fountain Cafe had WAY too much to choose from and we were in a rush...so we hopped into this place.  I was craving Udon so I tried theirs out.  :(  

It came out hot...it wasn't terrible ...*sigh* but that money could have gone to a better meal.  I wished SO BAD for Muracci's bomb-ass beef and vegetable udon (extra spicy).  My cousin had a salad with chicken on top.  She said it was alright...but then again, it WAS just leafy greens...can't exactly go wrong with lettuce.  (She doesnt put any dressing on her salads....cha....is that mind boddling or what...)  The fried veggies/tempura were not very good...:(  reeaally soggy.  

Sorry, Niji.  Muracci's is the golden child and you are the black sheep.  :(
author: Kat C.

description:
Generous portions, nice prices. The teriyaki salmon is tasty and comes with rice, salad (skip this, not good in any way), broccoli (extra points for this!) and miso soup.

I can definitely see myself returning here. One of the less depressing options for a quick and cheap FiDi lunch.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Customer service was really bad, I felt like the cashier was doing me a flavor by taking the order, he had no smile on his face 
Had the chicken teriyaki which was not full th cooked and hard to chew. Never ever going there again.
author: Raja K.

description: i avoided this place like the plague, being Japanese and all, but i saw someone eating a plate here with chicken, rice and broccoli.  how bad can it be? turns out, its not bad at all and when i want chicken, rice and broccoli or salmon, rice and broccoli, i come  here.  the miso soup tastes right too.
author: Wakako U.

description:
The only way you end up eating here is if you're wandering around Crocker Galleria and nothing looks good and you realize you haven't had Japanese food in awhile, and Niji's fried tempura goodness is starting to look appealing.

The boyfriend and I shared lunch bento boxes of teriyaki and tempura. It was very mediocre and we sort of regretted our meal by the end. There are better places to get a bento box. Unfortunately none of them are in the Financial District.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Food is consistently good, the owner and employees are very friendly and helpful. I wish the chairs were a bit more comfortable, but why nitpick? You're never sitting there for more than a half hour for lunch anyway.
author: Green Y.

description: This place is amazing!! Try their Cold Soba w/ Tempura. You'll be back every week!
author: Tom B.

description:
I ordered the Chicken Katsu.  It came with a lot of thick chicken breast meat (yeah because other mediocre places will either give you dark meat--not a fan--- or chicken that's been pounded super thin,with a mallet, within an inch of its life) and sauce on the side.  You also get some rice, miso soup and salad.

Miso soup - not overly salty which is a good thing

Chicken - juicy!  Like I said it's very hard to get good katsu and theirs is the best.  Moist and fried to perfection.

Salad - typical iceberg lettuce salad but I have to give props for the 1/4 slice of sweet tomato!

You also get a ice cream scoop of rice.  It's not a lot but w/ the price of rice these days, it's understandable.  Eh, I can do w/o the extra carb.

Service was quick.  Deduct one star because it's pricey Japanese food!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Not a bad idea for lunch. Depends on what you order. 

I usually get Hot Soba (comes with seaweed and imitation fishcakes) with Tempura (one shrimp, eggplant, broccoli, potato, carrot, cucumber). Pretty consistent and not too shabby for $6.95. I don't eat most of the tempura veggies (mostly 3 out of 5), so one time, I asked for just shrimp tempura. Which was a bad idea...because it only came with TWO shrimp. I was, at the very least, expecting three. Since then, I've just ordered regular tempura because I get more bang for my buck with the veggies.

Sometimes, I'll just order two orders of gyoza (12 gyoza total). It comes with a tangy, garlicky sauce and lemon wedges. I believe it's probably store bought gyoza, but I don't expect anything fancy, so I'm okay with it. The garlic sauce though, will overpower your tastebuds. I recommend having a dessert afterward to overcome the taste. Plus honestly, 12 gyoza is not filling, so I don't feel too bad having dessert afterwards. 

Average Total: $7.50 (no drinks)
author: Sandy L.

description:
I came to this place to give it a try because another yelper said that the tonkatsu wasn't bad.

He was utterly wrong.  It was probably the worst Tonkatsu I've ever had in my life.  It was tough as leather and had zero taste.  I read reviews where people say the food doesn't have taste, and I could never understand since food generally has some sort of taste.  Well, if I had to put my finger on it, the Tonkatsu tasted like cauliflower.  And it was probably just as tough.  Yeah, that bad.

The only redeeming thing was the amount of rice that they gave you.  The side salad was drenched in salad dressing.  And the miso was terrible (although, it's terrible in most places because it comes from a packet).

I should've known better as soon as I walked in.  I saw no asian worker there and no asian cooks.  That was a telltale sign that this was going to be bad.  

Tonkatsu - $8.78 incl. tax
Comes with salad (drenched in dressing), rice and miso soup
author: Jon K.

description:
Anyone who has been on Yelp as long as I have knows that you accumulate a lot of things. Regrets, fears, memories, and of course a number of articles of clothing. One of which was left w/ me as a friend had to make a speedy retreat from a North Beach bar. In her haste, she grabbed the wrong coat but the taxi was already there waiting. Long story short, I have her coat. 

So we meet at Niji which is at the Crocker Galleria. It's Thursday so Farmer's Market is on the ground floor and is bustling w/ activity. Niji is busy so my expectations are high. How high? My favorite place in SF for Japanese style noodles is Katana-Ya. My friend goes here often and can vouch for it. I'm a little taken back when she says she has never been to Katana-Ya. 

So I walk up to the counter and say "Ramen with tempura please." They don't serve ramen! I pick my expectations up from the floor and just say "I'll have what she is having." So I guess Udon w/ tempura will have to do. 

The wait is about 5 mins and I'm anxiously waiting for the soft pillowey noodles, the light/salty broth, the crips deep fried veggie goodness. What comes out is a huge bowl and a side plate of vege-tastic tempura bits. I'm running late so I eat very quickly. The bowl is huge, but the noodles are thin. They were good but not as chewy and soft as I would like Uron noodles to be. But you definitely get your money's worth. 

-1 star for no ramen, -1 star for thin udon noodles. I will go back though as it was a decent lunch and for 7 bucks, pretty reasonable.
author: Angelo F.

description:
Cheap, clean food.  Nice menu selection.
I'm a big fan of their tempura.  I usually get it with the soup combination.  The boxes are high quality and a great deal.
author: Ric S.

description:
Close to work. Its Decent for "mall food." nothing that special here. I had the shrimp and veggie tempura udon 6.99 and it only came with one shrimp--wth? Dude if a shrimp dish comes with only one shrimp they should have a discloser sign or something, weird. At least it had fishcake in the udon. Still though! 

Noodles were a bit squishier than I like but it was okay. I'm not particularly picky with my noodles--I love noodles and I'll eat anything noodley! 

Service was pretty bad, I received no thank you, you're welcome,please or come again. Just a grumpy man taking my order, and another grumpier man handing it to me.
author: Amy S.

description: I came here with pretty low expectations, just wanting a decent serving of chicken teriyaki. However, the chicken was pretty dry and ended up not very satisfied with my purchase.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Like another review said, this place is cheap, tasty and quick.  My chicken terriyaki bento box was only $8 and came with a lot of chicken, rice, salad, and miso soup. 
I don't recommend getting the tempura bento box b/c it comes with a ton of vegetable tempura and no meat.
author: Brian C.

description: cheap, tasty and quick... the salmon terriyaki is deelish, as is the tempura.  The lunch combo comes with miso, steamed broccoli and rice.   I dont frequent Niji often, but when I do I leave satisfied.
author: Rena H.

description:
Pretty good Japanese food, inexpensive, quick, and conveniently located for those in the FiDi. 

I like the Salmon Teriyaki and Chicken Teriyaki with either Tempura or California Roll. The salad and soup are also good.

I also like the Crocker Galleria Frequent Dining Card. Have your card stamped each time you make a purchase of $6+. When you have 8 stamps, redeem your card and receive free meal (up to $6, or $6 off your meal).
author: Desiree L.

description:
Very acceptable Japanese food for the area. Not stellar, but if you're really craving Japanese, this is fast, very convenient location, and not too expensive. 

The chicken katsu tasted fine. I had the mackerel special and it came with broccoli as well. 

Service is kind of rude, but considering the only interaction you have is at the cash register, it was ok. Lots of seating, indoor and outdoor, in the Galleria.
author: Grace Y.

description:
THIS RESTAURANT GAVE ME FOOD POISONING.

I ordered a California roll, and an unagi roll.  I thought the California roll seemed a bit fishy, but I figured, hey it's made of fish.  Taste wise, they were both incredibly mediocre.  

A few hours later, I had the WORST stomach ache.  Let's just say I spent the night lying on the bathroom floor.  I will NEVER go here again, I recommend others avoid Niji like the plague.
author: Laura C.

description:
Like doughnuts? Like Tempura? What if you could have both great tastes in one simple dish? Well boys and girls you can at Niji.

They must use the same doughnut compound, yes compound, because this doesn't remotely taste like any tempera batter should. Something different all together and not for the better. I had mixed tempura, shrimp was just ok, then it was time to dive in the larger than life serving of veggies. By the time I took my first bite I could tell this wasn't your basic formulary. I was good for two pieces, nothing more. Greasy and heavy. Salad dressing is straight from the midwest, all mayo with something to thin it out, Wouldn't eat this either.

In defense of what is passable:
Miso soup was really good
Servings are substantial

If you want bulk and cheap, this is your place.
author: Steve S.

description: I started coming here about two years ago, when I started working downtown and since then I have come here at least once a week, every week. When I really like a place, I will never disappoint the ownership. This might seem crazy, but I order the same exact dish every single time! The GYU-DON. I have become somewhat of a cult-figure here because of this. Where Igu (I believe that's his name) knows me instantly. He tells the chef as soon as I enter the doors to make a Gyu-Don so that it's basically ready for me as soon as I pay. Igu is one of the nicest dudes around and he's always got a smile on his face and a very carefree attitude. He's almost always behind the counter say wassup to him.
author: Michael C.

description: This is one of the few places in the Crocker Galleria that I will grab lunch from. Their Tempura is always really fresh. The white chicken meat can be bland and dry..but the salmon is pretty good!
author: Mimi T.

description:
Sometimes when its ass cold and i want something other than soup from the SF Soup Company to warm me up, i go to Niji's for the Hot Soba and Tempura.  The soba and the soup definitely hit the spot.  It thaws out the inner tundra within me.  Seriously, once i leave my bed i feel forever cold.  Maybe because i have no heart, but that's not important now.  The tempura that comes with this dish is decent consisting of a shrimp, carrot, potato, eggplant, 2 zucchinis and a broccoli deep fried in yummy tempura batter.  It never leaves me too full nor does it ever leave me still hungry.  The fact that it's quick, close by, and relatively inexpensive are all pluses, however there are its minuses.

If you enjoy sushi or anything of the raw ilk, I do not suggest eating here.  Stick to the cooked stuff, but then again their teriyaki stuff is just okay.  It can be a little dry but the portions aren't too shabby and it doesn't cost you an arm and a leg.  

Just stick to the soba.  If you don't like soba, udon is just as good.
author: Aaron G.

description: Being of part Japanese descent, I am a Jpn food snob and proud of it! So when I was on a lunch break, my co-worker suggested we check it out. Not bad I must say. They are fast, affordable, and tasty. I had the salmon teriyaki combination, which includes rice, miso soup, and for $1 extra a whole bunch of tempura!! Tasty tempura too! I will be back for sure.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Diet: (n) 1. A process of continuous improvement whereby one discovers new and ever more ingenious ways to starve.  2.  A national government body, as in Japan.  

There's really no need to eat lunch, except to satisfy my mental craving.  20 pounds of fat could keep me going for weeks, and I am working to get rid of it.  So, on a long walk, my imagination turns to Japanese food, the leanest food I can think of eating in a restaurant.   I stop in at the Crocker Galleria, at the Niji Grille.  

Chicken teriyaki donburi and a soda, $8.07.  

I take the plate out onto the balcony overlooking the shopping area.  The miso is delicious, that grainy texture that tells me I am consuming more than hot water.  Little tofu cubes.  

Two chicken breasts, dry but not too sweet.  

Broccoli.  

Rice.  

Sunlight.  

Warmth.  

Calm.  

The clock bells ring through the mall, echoing off the walls and skylight.  Sounds like Big Ben.  No, clearer.  Like the Ferry Building.  No, even clearer.  Like the bell tower at Avalon Bay in Catalina Island.  

Then Sunlight.  

Warmth.  

Calm.    
 
 
 
Why do I eat now?  
No need for food, I know that.  
It is food for thought.
author: David D.

description:
menu: http://www.shopatgalleria.com/directory/menus/niji.htm

The quality to price ratio is just right.  Vegetarian and vegan friendly.  The miso soup is fish based.  The Goyza are great.  Very fast service.  Open till 3:30PM unlike the crocker galleria site which says 6PM.
author: Joshua S.

description:
"The soba's ok, but its hard to screw up soba"

if you really really want japanese and dont want to go anywhere else because you're already here. 

This place is not horrible but they're competing with SF Japanese restaurants and thats really hard, everything i've had here is substandard but not necessarily bad. Also the service is a bit slow and they serve their soup to go in plastic containers (not paper) like SF soup co for example.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Yikes - this place was pretty below average.  The portions were relatively generous, but the tempura was underwhelming and the mackerel that I ordered was pretty gross (ordering the mackerel was probably my mistake).  Also, the teriyaki sauce that accompanied the mackerel was almost thinner than water.  All and all - I was unimpressed.  

Nonetheless, I may give the udon a chance someday when I can't be bothered walking to Yo Yo's or the "random asian place" around the corner.  Of course, the sushi boat place near Quizno's has a pretty awesome deal on tempura udon - so, on second thought, maybe I won't be back...
author: Matthew H.

description:
Drippy chicken on
rice. Price and service good but
meal disappointing

Dining Hall day dreams
return with this drab-ish dish.
Why did I bother?
author: Keith M.

description:
Japanese owned Japanese restaurants are just better than ones that are run by non-Japanese owners.  Take Niji Japanese Grille for example.  Best bowl of tempura udon I've had in a while.  Its all the little things that made it so good and seem so authentic.  Fried tofu skin, oshinko, seaweed, two different kinds of fishcake...all in excess and presented neatly in my bowl.  Plus they have Japanese chili pepper available upon request!  It was so good, I had it two days in a row.

I think they should have signs that say JAPANESE SUPERVISED to help consumers identify which Japanese restaurants are owned by Japanese people.  I say "supervised" because, let's face it, you know Mexicans are the ones actually making that shit.
author: Tommy O.

description:
This is the most decent place in the Crocker Galleria in my opinion although like all the other places there it gives me a gnarly stomach ache in the middle of the day in the office, which is the stuff ulcers and work-related illness are probably made of.

But anyway.

Their chicken teryaki is a great deal for almost too much chicken, miso, lots of broccoli, salad, rice, etc. Something like $8 which downtown is cheap. You can't sit down anyplace decent down there for less than $15 let alone the stomach ache. 

Yesterday we ate at Sam's Grill and paid $25 each and I had a stomach ache too but not the same kind, not the same kind people.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
An average/almost average lunch option.  The price is right and if you're trying to get some lighter fare in the galleria it stands as a possibility but honestly...you know, meh.

I had the beef donburi.  The teriyaki sauce is decent; the rice, reasonable.  The beef was too tendon-y/fatty for me.  I'm sort of weird about meat, I like obsessively eat around those pieces, and there was a lot of eating-around with this meal.

I dunno, it's lunch.
author: Oliver N.

description:
I may be an exception, but I haven't ever had a bad experience at this lunch destination.   Convenient to us busy dot com geeks, this grill on the upper floor of Crocker is usually crowded, but the food is worth it.    

I gave them four stars because they have the BEST chicken katsu that I could find in the city.   If anyone can think of  a better katsu shack, I'd be pleasantly surprised!
author: Daniel C.

description: I like their salmon teriyaki but they do not give enough for the price you pay. Kinda pricey.
author: Mich G.

description:
Dryest chicken teriyaki I've ever had.  Then I decided to give it another shot and tried the chicken katsu and that was better but still bland.  The rest of the combo offerings (salad, soup, vegatables and rice)  were decent and save it from getting One Star from me.  I'm too afraid to try the sushi.  I would agree with others that this is a passable place to eat if you are really craving japanese food.

Going to Crocker Galleria at lunch during the work week and seeing which places are packed is a good indication of the quality of the joint.  Needless to say, I've never seen this place too busy...
author: Tyrone I.

description:
If I need a quick and close fix for tempura and chicken katsu, I found it in Niji Japanese Grille. I don't normally flock to fast food Japanese food, but nonetheless during the cold days (when it was actually blistering cold) the miso soup was readily available to combo plates. 

To me I much rather prefer the Japanese restaurant ambiance and the prices are decent, but not for me when I am on a budget sometimes. I definitely will go back when my tempura craving caves in.
author: Jamie L.

description:
I have had many "I can't decide what to have for lunch" lunches here.

I have worked near the crocker galleria for 3 years now. Needless to say, I have eaten at every restaurant in it at least 30 times. Niji is one of them.

I am never excited to come here but it's always consistent. The rice , broccoli and miso soup are all very standard. The tempura is alright but is not great, the grilled dishes are very standard too.

I always enjoy getting the vegetarian sushi rolls here, as it's really hard to screw that up (unless of course, they give you un-ripe avocado). But in a sea of overpriced, crappy restaurants, Niji is a go-to for me.
author: Tala D.

description: The food is actually good tasting..my only concern, my shrimp was NOT properly cleaned!!! Yuck..
author: Y. Abigail H.

description:
Niji  offers good food at a fast pace. I like to get the  beef over rice. It comes with soup and broccoli  and I get a soda for $8. Not bad. Food is always fresh tasting and even when the line is out the door, I never wait more than 5 Min's.
I have had the tempura and it can sometimes be a bit greasy.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Prepare yourself for some mega dry chicken.  I ordered a curry rice not knowing that there was going to be chicken in it, but still I'll admit, pleasantly surprised by the addition.  So I took a few bites and pretty soon started to realize that the chicken was dry and overcooked; it looked like you could peel the pieces off as with string cheese...but even that would be more moist.  Chicken aside, the curry was alright and tasted fine with the rice, so I wasn't really going to complain.

Then, I looked at my friend's order and realized that she had barely touched her chicken teriyaki.  Now, I know it's a common assumption that you pretty much cannot go wrong with chicken teriyaki, but boy...never has the maxim been proven more right.  When you assume, you make an ass out of...you know the rest.  So I asked my friend about her chicken, and she told me it was really dry too.  I guess it wasn't just me.  

All of this leads me to deduce that either one chicken in the coop was suffering from major eczema or the folks at Niji just didn't know how to grill their chicken.
author: Philip W.

description:
I go for the udon and tempura. 

The tempura is the best I can find (so far, though that doesn't say  much for my abilities to find good tempura, but I digress): you can taste the vegetables! That's a plus.

I like it. What can I tell you. It's yummy and comforting on a cold day.
author: M O.

description:
A decent enough option in Crocker Galleria, the combo lunch is the way to go. One thing I love about this food court is that it's at least a step above the Burger King level of quality, so in terms of finding a decent and reasonable workday lunch, it's a reliable option.

There's plenty of seating in the extra seating rooms, of course, but also on nice days on their roof.
author: Nish N.

description:
On a yelper's advice I tried the chicken katsu. I will definitely go back. The miso was decent, but the katsu was delicious--fried perfectly with the meat still juicy.

A perfect little lunch, only not so little because there was so much chicken.
author: Brad C.

description: The food didn't taste as good as it looked.  I tried the beef teriyaki with California roll.  The beef was tough and fatty.  Not tender, not so great quality meat.  The miso soup tasted like chicken broth and wasn't too flavorful.  The salad dressing was okay, but unfortunately it was served over yellow-looking ice berg lettuce.  My coworker said the chicken teriyaki was rather dry.  I guess this place is cool if you're looking for a convenient, fast food jap place... Besides that, BLAH.
author: Tramy V.

description: Pretty bland, but sort of what I expected for the Galleria though.  I was a little surprised that a Japaneses restaurant had nothing but Mexican people working there.  A group of four colleagues and I split a bunch of different types of sushi.  All of it pretty much tasted the same.  I won't be back here anytime soon, but honestly probably never would have come in the first place if it was my choice.
author: Brian G.

description:
Whenever I take my well-deserved one hour lunch break, I am always faced with the same old question: do I want Quantity or Quality?

Whenever Quality wins, I end up walking too far, taking too long for lunch and spending way too much.  Whenever Quantity prevails, I go to Niji.

It's quick, inexpensive and decent.  I always get a bento box, and it is always literally bursting at the seams.  I opt for salmon teriyaki with a side of vegetable tempura bento box for $8.59.  Salmon is always overcooked, and vegetable tempura is battered so much, you'd think it was a victim of domestic violence.  Said box also comes with salad with too much dressing, steamed rice and ... ugh... broccoli.  I also get a box of edamame for $2.50.  It's lukewarm and nearly tasteless, but it's HUGE.

SIDE NOTE: You know how I feel about broccoli, right?  To quote Seinfeld, I "wouldn't eat broccoli if it was deep fried in chocolate sauce.  Vile weed!"

Anyway, if you're looking to get a lot of inexpensive below-average quality food in 7 minutes flat, Niji is for you.

By the way, the word "Niji" looks funny.  The "iji" with all those dots - hilarious.  What?  I am easily amused, OK?
author: Yan G.

description: Mildly edible, overpriced sushi. Overcooked, dry teriyaki. Haven't tried the udon yet, probably won't bother.
author: Aaron M.

description:
As far as fast-food Japanese food goes, Niji ranks pretty much as the best of the bunch. 

The combo plates really do offer exceptional value, and just about everything is cooked to order. If you gotta get your teriyaki fix on, this place is a good deal: skinless chicken breast meat that's cooked perfectly. Tempura is great; they even include eggplant, which more expensive places often leave out. I doubt I'd really come here for fresh sushi, but I can't see it being that horrible.

I often opt to get my food to go, but the restaurant seating isn't too purgatorial; the upstairs roof deck isn't bad either.
author: Aaron L.

description: I've only ordered the chicken teriyaki meal because it fills me up during lunch.  Good for the price especially for being located in the Galleria.  The first time I ordered 'to-go' the lady asked me something but I couldn't understand her mumbling so I just said 'no thanks' when I got my food she asked me something again but had no idea what she asked so I said 'no thank you' with a smile but she game me a look as if she was saying 'really? whatever".  I had no idea what she was saying and I felt really bad but she was mumbling like crazy!  I still will go here though.
author: Jesse C.

description:
My litmus test for good sushi is the miso soup... and this delivered. I dug the sushi, the tuna was that oh-so-satisfying deep pink color.

Next time I'm going tonkatsu. Deep fried pork. Yummmm.
author: Jen F.

description:
i got the meal teriyaki chicken with rice, salad, and miso soup.  The salad tasted ok, chicken a bit dried (due to the microwave I believe), and miso soup tasted like water (that is what happens when you add too much water and cut-cost in boiling a new batch).

Price is a bit steep, it's in the FiDi what do you expect?!
author: Elliot Y.

description:
Came here for lunch today and had a bowl of udon to counteract these cold winter days. At most it was just an average bowl of udon, nothing spectacular, nothing horrible. 

Service is decent and they're pretty quick.
author: Heather S.

description: A co-worker told me about this place. I'm crazy about sushi so I decided to try it out yesterday for lunch. I ordered the Salmon Teriyaki. It was ok, but the salmon tasted somewhat dry. I also ordered some california rolls which were better. It made up for the ok tasting salmon. Yay for free water.
author: Gerard Y.

description: Here are my list of items you should order and can't go wrong with: combination maki, California rolls, (hot) tempura soba or any udon dish.  I come here weekly and the service is very friendly as well as fast during the lunch rush.  The food here is tasty, but I won't call it extraordinary.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Like most others, I eat here frequently because my workplace is fairly close by.

Niji has the basic combo that I like. I usually order either Salmon Shioyaki or Teriyaki, which comes with miso soup, salad, rice and the salmon. And all this is only $7.58!! Breakfast at Starbucks is normally 5 bucks so you really can't beat it. Obviously you can't compare it with anything that is authentic...
author: T L.

description: I didn't expect much when I first went there, since it is in a fast food court kind of a place. I was very pleasantly surprised by how tasty the sushi were. I like the good selection of different kinds of vegetarian makis. Went back there the day after too. Price was good too. Order a huge amount of food for not even $20. Too bad I don't go to the city that often, but when I do, I will certainly think of this place.
author: Anne W.

description:
I have been going to Niji for years, from when i was a kid to now. I was lucky enough to score a job in the financial district so I could always go to Niji and have a great authentic japanese lunch.  

The best thing at Niji is the sushi, its always 100% fresh as well as super super super (did i mention super?) fast to produce. I order, i blink, food arrives. You can't beat that, really you can't.

The owners are some of the nicest people I have ever met, they always smile and truly take pride in their restaurant.  There are a good amount of  Japanese places open for lunch in the FiDi, but I have noticed that a lot of them don't have lines, being Japanese...if i see lines, that means its good, true fact. And Niji is always packed. 

I'm proud to say that i've been a loyal customer of Niji for all of these years, because I believe if you want good solid Japanese food in the FiDi Niji is perfect. 

Sometimes during the winter and summer, they have a really cute cashier too. His name starts with an F, i'll get his number one day.

I DEFINITELY APPROVE!
author: Eric T.

description: Teriyaki chicken and salmon are worth trying. Food comes fast and is filling. It's not to die for but it's worth going to once every couple months. No complaints but nothing spectacular either. I will repeat this place for sure, but more out of convenience of fast service / filling meals versus for phenomenal tasting food.
author: Tushar K.

description:
My workplace orders takeout from here. I usually get the Chicken katsu or the Tonkatsu. You can't lose with deep fried meat right? Anyway, you get a ton of meat, only one scoop of rice (no need to fill up on that) some standard iceberg lettuce salad, and a bowl of miso soup. You should definitely be full after eating it. Actually my office is all Japanese people and they usually order the udon. Don't know if it's the season or if it's good but they seem okay with it so you should be too!

Edit: I tried the Tempura Udon and the Tempura was oily and chewy. My coworkers told warned me but I had to try it anyway. Which leads me to believe that it's a trend and not a fluke.
author: Christopher U.

description:
One of those "in a pinch" Japanese joints.  You know what you're getting yourself into when you eat here.  

My beef teriyaki was all right, but why ask me how I'd like it prepared if you're just going to make it well done anyway?  

And too much dressing on the salad.  Too much.
author: Marcus C.

description:
We all have good and bad experiences with all types of services in our daily routine.  For me, Niji is a one of the good!

The wait is very average - on the short side.  Staff is friendly and fast.

Their Miso soup (and I love some good miso) is awesome.  Their chicken teriyaki is fantastic.  I love their Teriyaki Combo (salad, rice, broccoli and a nice portion of chicken).  

Today, I opted for a little less "low cal" option, and had the chicken Katsu.  Good stuff.  Not greasy, not re-warmed.  I love the katsu sauce- kind of a combination of Teriyaki and Worchesteshire sauce.. yummy!


While I was there, I watched a paper reciept fall from a tray of food that was being prepared- and it hit the floor.   I watched as the "front man" picked it up-to see what he would do.. IN the garbage it went.  WHEW... 

I suggest you give this place a try-  if you dont like it, Im sorry- but I am a fan.
author: Mike H.

description:
Wow... So stopped in to get a chicken donburi. What I got was dry chicken slathered in teriyaki sauce over rice.  Why don't they just call it teriyaki chicken in a rice bowl?

If you've ever had proper donburi, the meat is cooked with egg in a savory sauce.

When I asked them about it, they just gave me a blank stare..."Oh we don't do that way" 

I guess it's okay if you don't know any better.
author: Nopadon W.

description: I forgot the name of the thing I had . It was called salmon something . And no , it was not salmon teriyaki . Anywho , it tasted decent . The sauce that came with it was kind of nice . It also came with rice , salad , and miso soup which all tasted pretty decent . I also had the spicy tuna roll which was okay .. but not really something that stands out to me or that I'd rave about . It was almost forgettable .
author: Eileen L.

description:
Niji Japanese Grille in The Crocker Galleria is awesome. As a matter of fact, I go there about 5 days a week. No joke. For those of you who say the chicken teriyaki is dry, well, you are wrong. Another thing to remember is that unlike all the other CHEAP Japanese restaurants in SF, Niji uses all juicy, all white, breast meat, instead of, unhealthy, poor people mystery dark meat! It's clean, healthy, juicy, white meat! 
Not only is their chicken great, but also the beef teriyaki. I will admit, I did get the tempura six years ago and was very disappointed with the dipping sauce (key in great tempura), so I have stuck with the Chicken Teriyaki. Anyway, Niji is great. No msytery meat and a decent price.
author: Edward B.

description: Do you have a habit of going back to the same place that serves mediocre food?  I find myself here every other month, so the food can't be all that bad.  Maybe I'm giving it an extra star because of that.  Maybe I'm giving it because my husband said it was bad karma to badmouth a place that nice people work hard to run.  The rice is still dry as hell, though.  So there.
author: M L.

description: Their chicken katsu, California rolls and other inconspicuous menu items are fine - pretty good to-go prices. Just stay far away from the udon - it's a sticky, mushy mess.
author: Anna G.

description: It's good. They do a pretty good job with chicken katsu -- it's made fresh. I also like that they'll substitute broccoli for the pallid bit salad they usual serve with some combos. I always seem to deal with the same young guy with a ponytail. Haven't had much of their sushi (all maki). Oh, the soba noodle soup with tempura can be nice once in a while.
author: Tara M.

description: want some cheap japanese food that decent? especially great for a quick lunch. i usually just get a udon $6.45 on the windy sf days. crocker also has the stamp cards when you fill it up you get a meal for free. they also have bento boxes and sushi, though i'm not sure if i would trust their sushi.
author: Jen S.

description: Nothing special. The maki is hit or miss, chicken is usually pretty dry, but they are quick and convenient. Everything else on the menu is pretty standard food court quality Japanese food.
author: Sandra S.

description: I have a mixed review for this place.  This portions were generous and the service was quick, but my gyu don (thin slices of beef over rice) was really fatty! Of course that didn't stop me from eating the entire thing, but I would think that they could at least trim the large pieces of fat off the "lean" meat. It was sort of like eating sauteed bacon. Even though, I will come back to try more stuff for a better assessment.
author: Charlene C.

description: Had the Teriyaki Chicken plate...which came with rice, broccoli, teriyaki chicken, salad and miso soup. All in all, for a combination of taste, price ($7.76 with tax) and speed...this place is great! I am a big teriyaki fan, but haven't found too many good places....the teriyaki place behind my work at 555 market, is ok...but not that great. This plate leaves you feeling full, but not like you want to vomit afterwards. Service was about 3 minutes from order to eating...Quick lunch that didn;t taste like it was made quick...chicken slightly dry, but still very tasty and not smothered in sodium laced teriyaki sauce! Good deal and fast...GET SOME!!!
author: Jason S.

description:
It's my frequent lunch fix in FiDi. It's close, convenient, clean, quick and easy. They increased the price so it's not cheaper compare to other japanese restaurants in downtown. 

I always have the tempura udon, beef teriyaki don or combo with tempura or california maki, and salmon teriyaki. They are good and i like it here because you can get steamed broccoli instead of the salad.

I like their beef teriyaki compare to other japanese restaurants in downtown because the beef is so tender, medium cook and tasty.
author: sofie W.

description: Pretty mediocre.  One of those order at the counter places.  California rolls were around $3 for 6 pieces.  Tight and good.  Spicy Tuna Maki (4 large rolls that fell apart b/c the tuna pieces were strangely large and unwieldy).  I only went here b/c I was wandering around the Galleria on a hot day and wanted something cold to eat.  Wouldn't come here again unless I was carving for japanese and didn't feel like looking elsewhere.  For california roll and Spicy Tuna Maki, it was $9 and some change.  Like the others have said, this place is nothing special.
author: Karen L.

description: I hate that there are not many japanese restaurants in the financial district ... so my boyfriend and i settled here for lunch to fill our japanese food craving, but we with an even bigger craving.
author: Jen P.

description: This place sucks period.  Chicken teriyaki taste like rubber.
author: Tony C.

description: when there's not enough funds in the wallet to afford akiko's, i head over to the crocker galleria for some decent japanese food.  california roll is good (more like kani, not fat chunks of artifical crab), and their tempura is great - not overbattered at all, and also not very greasy.  chicken katsu is also good - very generous portions!  when i'm trying to eat healthy (to make up for overindulging all the other times i eat =P), the salmon teriyaki is good, again huge portion.  sub broccoli for the wilty salad w/ a strange dressing.  and when you've only got a couple of dollars to spend and want to be full and healthy (as in something more substantial than a diet coke and a bag of chips), go for the broccoli w/ teriyaki sauce over rice.
author: Jen P.

description: the beef is super good.  i like the udon and the gyoza.  the gyoza is crispy yet delightful.  mmm. makes me want some more.  I have eaten here many times and I still come back for more!
author: con c.

description: okay jap food.. comes in small portion.. sushi not as fulling so order two to three different kinds of sushi... their chicken teriyaki are delicious but that my favorite jap dish i always order... plenty of seating indoor and outdoor.. if it a sunny day.. so pretty...
author: Lily T.
